<div class="mck-o-sidebar mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Findustries%2Feducation%2Four%20insights%2Freimagining%20education%20in%20menap%2Freimagining-education-in-menap.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c" target="_self" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Article" data-layer-file-name="reimagining-education-in-menap" data-layer-report-name="reimagining-education-in-menap>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (11 pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div></div>

<p><strong>Many countries</strong> in the region embracing the Middle East, North Africa, and Pakistan (MENAP) faced profound economic, political, and educational challenges even before the COVID-19 pandemicfor example, ongoing conflict in countries such as Iraq, Libya, Syria, and Yemen caused severe disruptions to the provision of education. COVID-19 further exacerbated the challenges facing the educational sector: about 100 million students in the Middle East, North Africa, and Pakistan couldnt attend school in person for 4.5 to 14.0 months.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="91792be9-bbc9-4488-bc61-886b4f23ee55"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="91792be9-bbc9-4488-bc61-886b4f23ee55" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Jimmy de la Torre, Nancy Law, Gary Wong, and David Woo, A global framework of reference on digital literacy skills for indicator 4.4.2, United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization Institute for Statistics, 2018.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>But the pandemic also accelerated the shift to digital in education and spurred innovation and agility that made it possible for teaching to continue remotely, even in countries with a poor digital infrastructure. By building on the lessons of the past two years and leveraging educational technology beyond the pandemic, the regions countries have an opportunity to close the gap, in both educational outcomes and digital literacy, between themselves and the rest of the world. In particular, sharing best practices and innovations among MENAP countries would help educational standards to rise across them.</p>
<p>The regions current challenges include a failure to attain basic levels of education, bottom-level performance in international assessments, and the widespread lack of digital literacy.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="75dcf56b-b66a-4dbc-a63e-31ca3c77a7ee"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="75dcf56b-b66a-4dbc-a63e-31ca3c77a7ee" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Jimmy de la Torre, Nancy Law, Gary Wong, and David Woo, A global framework of reference on digital literacy skills for indicator 4.4.2, United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization Institute for Statistics, 2018.</span></span></span></a></span> Our research has identified six key elements for overcoming these obstacles. If addressed, they could improve educational outcomes across the region.</p>
<h2>The MENAP region currently trails in educational outcomes</h2>
<p>Students in the Middle Eastern and North African countries that took part in the 2018 PISA<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f972e46d-1fc1-4aeb-ac22-c88aafb6030e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f972e46d-1fc1-4aeb-ac22-c88aafb6030e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Programme for International Student Assessment.</span></span></span></a></span> test had scores some 20 percent lower than the average among the members of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD). Half of all children in the MENAP region fail to reach a basic level of learning in primary school, compared with 37 percent in the world as a whole and 25 percent in the OECD countries.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="45b0744f-9dd5-45a5-ad94-7202fd72d4d9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="45b0744f-9dd5-45a5-ad94-7202fd72d4d9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Joo Pedro Azevedo et al., Simulating the potential impacts of Covid-19 school closures on schooling and learning outcomes: A set of global estimates, World Bank, June 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> Differences in educational outcomes within the MENAP region reflect factors such as major differences in income among countries and ongoing school disruptions. The United Arab Emirates (UAE) is the only MENAP country where more than 60 percent of children reach a basic level of primary education. Lower numbers prevail in countries where challenges external to the educational system affect schools. In Yemen, for example, less than 10 percent of children achieve a basic level of learning in primary education (Exhibit 1).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/education/our%20insights/reimagining%20education%20in%20menap/svgz-reimagining-education-in-menap-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="In a 2014 projection, only 37 percent of children would reach a basic level of learning in primary school by 2020; COVID-19 may have set this back further." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/education/our%20insights/reimagining%20education%20in%20menap/svgz-reimagining-education-in-menap-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Half of all children in the MENAP region fail to reach a basic level of learning in primary school, compared with 37 percent in the world.</p></blockquote></div>
<p>According to UNICEF,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1eb5c401-02a9-49df-9079-c318518d83e3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1eb5c401-02a9-49df-9079-c318518d83e3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The acronym reflects the former name (United Nations International Childrens Emergency Fund) of what is now officially the United Nations Childrens Fund.</span></span></span></a></span> most MENAP countries perform near the bottom in international assessments, such as PIRLS<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="50db2261-9e14-4c7d-b4fd-1caa2b6df09d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="50db2261-9e14-4c7d-b4fd-1caa2b6df09d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The Progress in International Reading Literacy Study.</span></span></span></a></span> and TIMSS,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="75b61fba-63df-4bfe-870e-6c93b7b041fd"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="75b61fba-63df-4bfe-870e-6c93b7b041fd" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The Trends in International Mathematics and Science Study.</span></span></span></a></span> and all countries in the region fall below the average. UNICEF suggests that traditional teacher-centered approaches, rote learning, and outdated curricula contribute to the shortcomings in the development of skills needed for lifelong learning and employability.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="af6c2e32-ddff-454a-b782-5f9f88985d04"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="af6c2e32-ddff-454a-b782-5f9f88985d04" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For more information, see Education: Middle East and North Africa, UNICEF.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>The MENAP countries also lag behind others in digital literacy and in access to the internet. Internet penetration in the region has increased exponentially over the past two decadesfrom less than
5 percent in 2000 to more than 60 percent in 2020.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b5518759-c672-4108-bb82-f038f87ba4f4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b5518759-c672-4108-bb82-f038f87ba4f4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Individuals using the Internet (% of population) - Arab World, World Bank.</span></span></span></a></span> However, it remains highly uneven across and within countries, ranging from over 100 percent in Qatar and the UAE to 44.7 percent in Pakistan and only 25.9 percent in Yemen.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b0051450-db2d-4890-8c62-e6803b561136"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b0051450-db2d-4890-8c62-e6803b561136" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Internet World Stats, updated March 31, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> Within countries, vulnerable and lower-income people are less likely to use the internet, and that will probably increase the digital divide and exacerbate inequalities.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8151983a-66ba-4a6d-af2b-97b9ddf1288b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8151983a-66ba-4a6d-af2b-97b9ddf1288b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Daniella Raz, The Arab worlds digital divide, Arab Barometer, September 25, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>On average, in MENAP countries that participated in the 2018 PISA survey, 70 percent of schools gave students access to the internet, a level below that of the OECDs members and partners.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5d767727-64aa-4870-a1d4-0d508477c721"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5d767727-64aa-4870-a1d4-0d508477c721" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">TIMSS 2019 international results in mathematics and science, TIMSS & PIRLS International Study Center, Lynch School of Education, Boston College.</span></span></span></a></span> Teachers in the region had access to fewer internet-linked computers at school, and fewer students had access to the internet and to a computer for schoolwork at home.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5caaf67f-350e-43db-864b-56ab2941debe"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5caaf67f-350e-43db-864b-56ab2941debe" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">MENAP countries that participated as OECD partners in 2018 include Jordan, Lebanon, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, and the UAE. See PISA 2018 results, OECD, September 29, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> A key issue that emerged in Pakistan in particular is that parents (and communities
more generally) do not consider digital literacy
a top priority.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="34b7f210-76ae-49d8-b78d-6cefc6dcb736"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="34b7f210-76ae-49d8-b78d-6cefc6dcb736" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Ashir Ahmed and Jason Sargent, Theory of change: Driving a digital school in rural Pakistan, First Monday, November 27, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Unequal access and poor educational outcomes are further exacerbated in countries, such as Iraq, Lebanon, Syria, and Yemen, facing grave economic and political challenges. By the end of 2017, the number of unschooled children in the region increased to more than 14.3 milliona level last seen a decade before. In Iraq, Libya, Syria, and Yemen, upward of 8,850 educational facilities have been lost to conflicts.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="28bf1698-44cd-4487-8eb9-2bf3c05227d4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">15</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="28bf1698-44cd-4487-8eb9-2bf3c05227d4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For more information, see Education: Middle East and North Africa, UNICEF.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h2>COVID-19 has disrupted the regions educational landscape</h2>
<p>The COVID-19 pandemic has not only intensified preexisting challenges and accelerated trends but also created the impetus for change. In the world as a whole, the number of children physically absent from school increased from 258.0 million in 2018 to 1.2 billion in 2020, including almost 100.0 million in the Middle East and North Africa.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3a301aab-47dd-45f5-a7ab-52e53ccace04"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">16</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3a301aab-47dd-45f5-a7ab-52e53ccace04" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Nikita Sharma, Torn safety nets: How COVID-19 has exposed huge inequalities in global education, World Economic Forum, June 5, 2020; COVID-19 response in education, UNICEF.</span></span></span></a></span> Every country in the region has been affected by the pandemic, to a greater or lesser extent, so many students cannot attend school, and some had limited or no access to live instruction during the lockdown phase.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8b70f7f6-a4ba-4a25-ba54-d8413f9ac27b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">17</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8b70f7f6-a4ba-4a25-ba54-d8413f9ac27b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>COVID-19 Learning Losses: Rebuilding Quality Learning for All in the Middle East and North Africa</em>, UNESCO, UNICEF, and World Bank, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> Since the pandemics start, schools in the region have been fully or partially closed for an average of more than ten monthsranging from 4.5 in Egypt to more than 14 in Iraq.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="01e18e6d-eff1-432d-978a-c30ad04974e5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">18</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="01e18e6d-eff1-432d-978a-c30ad04974e5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Dashboards on the global monitoring of school closures caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, UNESCO, November 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Globally, the pandemic-era combination of school closures and loss of livelihoods could result in an average shortfall of 6.4 months, according to <a href="/industries/education/our-insights/how-covid-19-caused-a-global-learning-crisis">McKinseys latest research</a>. In addition, the loss of time in school, compounded by additional regression in learning, could mean that grade-three children from low- and middle-income countries will have levels of learning one year lower than expected by the time they reach grade ten.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f6ff8995-ee24-414c-bc8a-0640ed392300"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">19</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f6ff8995-ee24-414c-bc8a-0640ed392300" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Carolina Alban Conto et al., COVID-19: Effects of school closures on foundational skills and promising practices for monitoring and mitigating learning loss, UNICEF, October 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Uneven digital literacy and uneven access to affordable, reliable internet connections and devices have further deepened inequities in educational outcomes. A McKinsey analysis in the United States has shown that students from vulnerable households are less likely to experience quality remote instruction. The result is an estimated
loss of more than 12 months of learningnearly double the average.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="37baa4af-1d03-40ec-a0e4-d82cf9e60db9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">20</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="37baa4af-1d03-40ec-a0e4-d82cf9e60db9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For the full McKinsey Global Institute report, see Emma Dorn, Bryan Hancock, Jimmy Sarakatsannis, and Ellen Viruleg, <a href="/industries/education/our-insights/covid-19-and-student-learning-in-the-united-states-the-hurt-could-last-a-lifetime">COVID-19 and student learning in the United States: The hurt could last a lifetime</a>, June 1, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>But in the MENAP countries (as in others), the pandemic has also accelerated the digital shift in education. Saudi Arabia, for example, has implemented a well-crafted, technology-driven response. During the pandemic, the Ministry of Education (MoE) introduced and then scaled up several major e-learning platforms (including Madrasati for primary and secondary students and Rawdati for kindergarteners) while it ramped up efforts to give needy students access to devices.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d09bcd8f-32bd-4f27-aaf0-9340ffba2f28"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">21</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d09bcd8f-32bd-4f27-aaf0-9340ffba2f28" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Andreas Blom, Anna Boni, and Laura Gregory, Learning from Saudi Arabias journey to digital and distance education, World Bank,
    February 8, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Initial user feedback suggests that both platforms have had significant benefits for students and teachers alike.</p>
<p>Even in countries with a limited digital infrastructure, the rapid shift to remote learning has accelerated the uptake of educational technologies that give vulnerable and remote populations access to education. Bahrain, Jordan, Lebanon, and Morocco have used TV channels to broadcast distance-learning content: the Alsama Project, for example, streams English-language lessons for children in Lebanese refugee camps. Jordan has also promoted the use of existing online platforms, such as Microsoft Teams and Edraak. Morocco and Oman have partnered with telecom companies to offer students free internet access on a wide variety of educational websites and online platforms.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="880597ca-0c52-4c92-83d3-d58e5c79b2c7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">22</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="880597ca-0c52-4c92-83d3-d58e5c79b2c7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Educational response to COVID-19 from Jordan and other Arab countries, Queen Rania Foundation, April 13, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h2>An opportunity to reimagine the regions educational systems</h2>
<p>COVID-19 has spurred the imagination and created the potential for change. People in the MENAP region now have an opportunity to rethink how its educational systems can shape the citizens of tomorrow.</p>
<p>Our research has identified six elements of success for a reimagined educational system: technology-enabled learning for every child; enhanced teacher quality to improve student outcomes; technology as an enabler of mastery-based, personalized learning; whole-child education; the creation of pathways for lifelong learning; and structural enablers to allocate resources equitably.</p>
<h3>Technology-enabled learning for every child</h3>
<p>Educational technology could improve access to quality education in the MENAP region, especially given its expanding penetration by the internet and smartphones. Tablets are now available for $35, which in some MENAP countries could put high-quality instruction directly in the hands of students and provide teachers with excellent, easy-to-follow lesson plans.</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Educational technology could improve access to quality education in the MENAP region, especially given its expanding penetration by the internet and smartphones.</p></blockquote></div>
<p>Governments could consider several ways of supporting tech-enabled instruction and better educational outcomes. To improve access to online resources, for example, education ministries could work with mobile operators to zero-rate educational websites, request that telecom providers shape bandwidth to prioritize education-related data and services, or consider lifting data caps on free internet access for students. Other moves that could support remote learning include enhancing the availability of voice-over-internet-protocol (VOIP) services, tapping universal-service funds, distributing more devices for home use (as Egypt did in response to school closures), and setting up free local Wi-Fi access points where students can upload work and download content.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f2547de3-4cf8-4641-98d3-b2d18015f61b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">23</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f2547de3-4cf8-4641-98d3-b2d18015f61b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">World Bank Blogs, How ministries of education work with mobile operators, telecom providers, ISPs and others to increase access to digital resources during COVID-19-driven school closures (coronavirus), blog entry by Michael Trucano, April 2, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>The UAEs MoE has taken a number of steps to ensure the successful implementation of distance learning.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="44fe9cac-2cd5-4627-921f-fdc6bda05498"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">24</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="44fe9cac-2cd5-4627-921f-fdc6bda05498" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Distance learning in times of COVID-19, UAE, August 23, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> Besides helping teachers to make the switch, the ministry established two advanced operations centers and facilitated a technical helpline for students and parents to ensure a smooth IT experience and effective communication between students and teachers. Families with no home internet connection received a free mobile-internet package, and the ministry also collaborated with Al Yah Satellite Communications to provide free satellite broadband services in areas lacking connectivity. Private schools were required to implement distance learning but allowed to use their own systems for that purpose.</p>
<h3>Enhanced teacher quality to improve student outcomes</h3>
<p>The importance of better teachers has been highlighted by school closures, which revealed variations in the quality of instruction.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="bde48787-60fe-4dc7-aed1-46945a91706b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">25</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="bde48787-60fe-4dc7-aed1-46945a91706b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>COVID-19 Learning Losses</em>, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> Technology cannot replace a great teacher, who may change
a students life trajectory. However, it can reduce workloads and improve the quality of education through tech-enabled teacher training and development; simulation-based instruction, for example,
is valuable and risk free. At the beginning of the pandemic, the UAEs MoE conducted a one-week remote professional-training course for more than 25,000 government schoolteachers and administrators and more than 9,200 private-school teachers and principals. It also collaborated with Hamdan Bin Mohammed Smart University
to launch a free online course about how to operate online classrooms.</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>On average, high-performing teachers can raise the performance of students by 53 percentage points over that of similar students with low-performing teachers.</p></blockquote></div>
<p>Good teachers are critical to the performance and educational growth of students: on average, high-performing teachers can raise the performance of students by 53 percentage points over that of similar students with low-performing teachers.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0f4af303-478a-401b-af3c-6b506b882904"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">26</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0f4af303-478a-401b-af3c-6b506b882904" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Creating effective teaching and learning environments: First results from TALIS, OECD, 2009.</span></span></span></a></span> <a href="/industries/education/our-insights/how-the-worlds-best-performing-school-systems-come-out-on-top">Teachers now work</a> about 50 hours a week globally but spend only 20 to 40 percent of their time on instruction and engagement with students; the rest is devoted to administrative responsibilities, evaluation and feedback, preparation, and other nonteaching activities (Exhibit 2). As this workload continues to grow, <a href="/industries/education/our-insights/how-artificial-intelligence-will-impact-k-12-teachers">technology could free up 20 to 30 percent
of the time of teachers</a>, allowing them to spend a greater proportion of the day engaging with studentswhich could improve educational outcomes. For example, <a href="/industries/education/our-insights/how-artificial-intelligence-will-impact-k-12-teachers">AI and digital platforms could help to assess students</a> (Exhibit 3).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/education/our%20insights/reimagining%20education%20in%20menap/svgz-reimagining-education-in-menap-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Teachers work about 50 hours a week, with the bulk of their time spent on preparation, instruction, coaching and advising, and evaluation and feedback." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/education/our%20insights/reimagining%20education%20in%20menap/svgz-reimagining-education-in-menap-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/education/our%20insights/reimagining%20education%20in%20menap/svgz-reimagining-education-in-menap-ex3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="As teacher workload continues to grow, technology could free up 20 to 30 percent of teachers time." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/education/our%20insights/reimagining%20education%20in%20menap/svgz-reimagining-education-in-menap-ex3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h3>Technology as an enabler of personalized, mastery-based learning</h3>
<p>Several existing platforms, which already combine instruction and assessment with a variety of content and resources, provide real-time feedback to both students and teachers through data visualization dashboards. The use of these platforms could make it easier for schools to collect data, track educational outcomes, and intervene to correct course more frequently rather than rely on periodic standardized tests, such as PIRLS, PISA, and TIMSS, which are given every three years on average.</p>
<p>In the MENAP region, ministries of education have used existing platforms and created new ones
in response to the pandemic. Jordan, for example, used MS Teams and Edraak (an Arabic-language open-access platform) for both K12 and continuous learning. In March 2020, Morocco launched a
new remote-learning platform, Telmid TICE, which 600,000 students access daily. In Qatar, Mzeed, accessible via website or app, was developed to help students and teachers access textbooks in PDF format and to provide model questions and answers, as well as other tools.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ff581a57-f559-4f03-8071-f16a04a74337"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">27</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ff581a57-f559-4f03-8071-f16a04a74337" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Safaa Kasraoui, 600,000 students access Moroccos remote education website each day, Morocco World News, April 2, 2020; Nabeela, Ministry of Education launches Mzeed Educational Platform, iloveqatar.net, November 12, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Across the board, we found that providing information and communications technology (ICT) for teachers rather than students works best. However, a blended approach, combining teacher- and student-focused technologies, may have a still more beneficial impact.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="36c6bd59-8b71-4096-9e79-13d2d32812f8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">28</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="36c6bd59-8b71-4096-9e79-13d2d32812f8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Jo Shan Fu, ICT in education: A critical literature review and its implications, <em>International Journal of Education and Development using Information and Communication Technology</em>, Volume 9, Issue 1, 2013.</span></span></span></a></span> For example, teacher-focused technologies (such as data projection) promote maximum engagement between students and teachers and have been shown to raise PISA science scores. Giving students access to computers with internet connections (a student-focused approach) also improves scores by empowering students
to work individually at school or at home. Increasing access toand combiningthese educational technologies could give students in the MENAP region a recipe for success.</p>
<p>Improving teacher-focused technologies tailored to the needs of individual students is critical to help them reach grade-level and subject standards. In a study on K12 teachers in the region, 57 percent of those queried reported that the digital resources they received were not sufficient for their students to achieve appropriate educational standards.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0e4b5d07-0425-467c-9157-806946c8f336"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">29</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0e4b5d07-0425-467c-9157-806946c8f336" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>COVID-19 Learning Losses</em>, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> The study showed that the most acute needs for digital enhancement are in elementary-school science, elementary-school English-language arts, and middle-school social studies. It is expected that a 75 percent increase in the use of digital tools will be required to meet the future needs of the MENAP regions students in a personalized way.</p>
<h3>Whole-child education</h3>
<p>An increasing amount of evidence suggests that teaching should focus on more than pure academics and instead foster a whole-child education.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="aac6149d-15c2-48ca-9c7c-ea29df2101a4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">30</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="aac6149d-15c2-48ca-9c7c-ea29df2101a4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Adele Diamond, The evidence base for improving school outcomes by addressing the whole child and by addressing skills and attitudes, not just content, <em>Early Education and Development</em>, 2010.</span></span></span></a></span> In fact, the biggest predictor of success for students in the region is mindset: the 2018 PISA survey determined that a motivated mindset was twice as important as an orientation to the subject matter for <a href="/industries/education/our-insights/how-to-improve-student-educational-outcomes-new-insights-from-data-analytics">PISA science scores</a>. Mindset comprises
five dimensions: <em>motivation calibration</em>, the ability to identify what motivation means in day-to-day life; <em>motivation</em>, the desire to succeed and receive good grades; <em>instrumental motivation</em>, how useful the subject will be for future lives and careers; a <em>sense of belonging</em>, how accepted the learner feels in school; and <em>test anxiety</em>, how anxious the learner is when taking a test.</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>An increasing amount of evidence suggests that teaching should focus on more than pure academics and instead foster a whole-child education.</p></blockquote></div>
<p>Motivation calibration was shown to be the factor contributing most to success (Exhibit 4): for example, <a href="/industries/education/our-insights/how-to-improve-student-educational-outcomes-new-insights-from-data-analytics">students with good motivation calibration scored, on average, 14 percent higher</a> on PISA than those with poor motivation calibration, and low-income students with higher motivation calibration were more likely to succeed than low-income students with poor motivation calibration.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 4</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/education/our%20insights/reimagining%20education%20in%20menap/svgz-reimagining-education-in-menap-ex4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Motivation calibration emerges as the most important general mindset dimension for improved science scores in the Middle East and North Africa." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/education/our%20insights/reimagining%20education%20in%20menap/svgz-reimagining-education-in-menap-ex4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>An educational system could therefore consider using a broader approach, going beyond the traditional acquisition of skills to encompass empowering mindsets. This goal will require competency frameworks to strengthen values and attitudes across the curriculum, a focus on future skills,
and a reduced emphasis on technical competencies (given automation trends and the rapid obsolescence of knowledge).</p>
<h3>Creating pathways for lifelong learning</h3>
<p>Rapidly accelerated shifts in degree offerings and delivery models mean that lifelong learning
no longer starts in higher education: rather, it is a muscle that can be developed by high-school students, who can look beyond their brick-and-mortar schools for certifications.</p>
<p>The trend of preparing students for lifelong learning, especially in coding and digital literacy, has been accelerating globally. The MENAP region has a few best-practice cases. For instance, INJAZ Al-Arab,
a nongovernmental organization (NGO) that targets youth workforce readiness, financial literacy, and entrepreneurship, partners with 92,905 volunteers, 4,000 schools, 426 universities, and 13 ministries
of education across the region. It has helped more than 4.4 million students to bridge the gap between education and the labor force.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a28d6690-0d5b-4902-bc71-45cb21c0d00e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">31</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a28d6690-0d5b-4902-bc71-45cb21c0d00e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Empowering the young minds of MENA, INJAZ Al-Arab, 2020, statistics as of June 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> In Lebanon, the nonprofit CodeBrave works with schools and NGOs to empower students from disadvantaged backgrounds, including refugees, by teaching them to teach themselves and solve problems, as well as digital literacy.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5ea395b1-9038-43c7-9e29-4881cdfb62c5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">32</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5ea395b1-9038-43c7-9e29-4881cdfb62c5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For further information, see Social change through tech education, CodeBrave, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h3>Structural enablers to allocate resources equitably</h3>
<p>The MENAP countries could help unleash the potential of technology in the classroom by considering changes to policies and regulatory frameworks. Governments can, for example, use performance-based funding to align quality with resources and empower all children. They could also engage the private sector, which has the resources to
deliver quality education efficiently at the scale required to meet growing demand. In fact, governments might consider shifting their role from operators to enablers and regulators, using targeted funding to ensure access for underprivileged students.</p>
<p>Finally, as educational systems shift from skills-based to values- and attitudes-based learning, parental engagement will become increasingly important. During the pandemic, Qatar and the UAE provided parents with guidelines and advice to help them
fulfill their new role of supporting their childrens remote learning at home.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2b627bc1-ea9e-416a-a417-3cf2768cecc0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">33</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2b627bc1-ea9e-416a-a417-3cf2768cecc0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Open Development & Education, Educational response to COVID-19 from Jordan and other Arab countries, blog entry by Nour Awamleh, April 6, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> In Bahrain and Jordan, schools mostly used WhatsApp and Facebook to communicate with parents and update them about their childrens progress.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3226748d-8d40-46f2-8abf-5d2baa25d6cf"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">34</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3226748d-8d40-46f2-8abf-5d2baa25d6cf" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Social change through tech education.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<hr>
<p>The time to reimagine and shape the future of education in the MENAP region is nowand this has never seemed more urgent. As the social and economic toll of the COVID-19 crisis continues to unfold, innovative and timely investments in the regions human capital are the surest way to help countries weather the crisis and prepare for a
rapidly changing world. We see four broad actions to establish a new lifelong-learning model that would prepare the populations of the MENAP region for the future of work.</p>
<ol>
    <li>Invest smartly in educational technology to improve digital literacy and support teachers inside and outside the classroom.</li>
    <li>Adopt holistic education frameworks that focus on values, mindsets, skills, and competencies.</li>
    <li>Embed lifelong learningespecially in basic technological literacy, workforce readiness, and cognitive skillsacross the education journey.</li>
    <li>Engage the private sector effectively to enhance the efficiency, delivery, and relevance of education.</li>
</ol>
<p>These imperatives will require the mobilization of parents, students, teachers, school leaders, governments, and employers. Meanwhile, educational institutions will need to find new ways of fixing the old path and charting new paths and solutions
to reimagine education going forward.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" 1]]\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMany countries\u003c/strong\u003e in the region embracing the Middle East, North Africa, and Pakistan (MENAP) faced profound economic, political, and educational challenges even before the COVID-19 pandemic\u0026mdash;for example, ongoing conflict in countries such as Iraq, Libya, Syria, and Yemen caused severe disruptions to the provision of education. COVID-19 further exacerbated the challenges facing the educational sector: about 100 million students in the Middle East, North Africa, and Pakistan couldn\u0026rsquo;t attend school in person for 4.5 to 14.0 months.[[footnote 1]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut the pandemic also accelerated the shift to digital in education and spurred innovation and agility that made it possible for teaching to continue remotely, even in countries with a poor digital infrastructure. By building on the lessons of the past two years and leveraging educational technology beyond the pandemic, the region\u0026rsquo;s countries have an opportunity to close the gap, in both educational outcomes and digital literacy, between themselves and the rest of the world. In particular, sharing best practices and innovations among MENAP countries would help educational standards to rise across them.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe region\u0026rsquo;s current challenges include a failure to attain basic levels of education, bottom-level performance in international assessments, and the widespread lack of digital literacy.[[footnote 2]] Our research has identified six key elements for overcoming these obstacles. If addressed, they could improve educational outcomes across the region.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eThe MENAP region currently trails in educational outcomes\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eStudents in the Middle Eastern and North African countries that took part in the 2018 PISA[[footnote 3]] test had scores some 20 percent lower than the average among the members of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD). Half of all children in the MENAP region fail to reach a basic level of learning in primary school, compared with 37 percent in the world as a whole and 25 percent in the OECD countries.[[footnote 4]] Differences in educational outcomes within the MENAP region reflect factors such as major differences in income among countries and ongoing school disruptions. The United Arab Emirates (UAE) is the only MENAP country where more than 60 percent of children reach a basic level of primary education. Lower numbers prevail in countries where challenges external to the educational system affect schools. In Yemen, for example, less than 10 percent of children achieve a basic level of learning in primary education (Exhibit 1).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n[[PullQuote 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eAccording to UNICEF,[[footnote 5]] most MENAP countries perform near the bottom in international assessments, such as PIRLS[[footnote 6]] and TIMSS,[[footnote 7]] and all countries in the region fall below the average. UNICEF suggests that traditional teacher-centered approaches, rote learning, and outdated curricula contribute to the shortcomings in the development of skills needed for lifelong learning and employability.[[footnote 8]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe MENAP countries also lag behind others in digital literacy and in access to the internet. Internet penetration in the region has increased exponentially over the past two decades\u0026mdash;from less than\n5 percent in 2000 to more than 60 percent in 2020.[[footnote 9]] However, it remains highly uneven across and within countries, ranging from over 100 percent in Qatar and the UAE to 44.7 percent in Pakistan and only 25.9 percent in Yemen.[[footnote 10]] Within countries, vulnerable and lower-income people are less likely to use the internet, and that will probably increase the digital divide and exacerbate inequalities.[[footnote 11]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOn average, in MENAP countries that participated in the 2018 PISA survey, 70 percent of schools gave students access to the internet, a level below that of the OECD\u0026rsquo;s members and partners.[[footnote 12]] Teachers in the region had access to fewer internet-linked computers at school, and fewer students had access to the internet and to a computer for schoolwork at home.[[footnote 13]] A key issue that emerged in Pakistan in particular is that parents (and communities\nmore generally) do not consider digital literacy\na top priority.[[footnote 14]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUnequal access and poor educational outcomes are further exacerbated in countries, such as Iraq, Lebanon, Syria, and Yemen, facing grave economic and political challenges. By the end of 2017, the number of unschooled children in the region increased to more than 14.3 million\u0026mdash;a level last seen a decade before. In Iraq, Libya, Syria, and Yemen, upward of 8,850 educational facilities have been lost to conflicts.[[footnote 15]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19 has disrupted the region\u0026rsquo;s educational landscape\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe COVID-19 pandemic has not only intensified preexisting challenges and accelerated trends but also created the impetus for change. In the world as a whole, the number of children physically absent from school increased from 258.0 million in 2018 to 1.2 billion in 2020, including almost 100.0 million in the Middle East and North Africa.[[footnote 16]] Every country in the region has been affected by the pandemic, to a greater or lesser extent, so many students cannot attend school, and some had limited or no access to live instruction during the lockdown phase.[[footnote 17]] Since the pandemic\u0026rsquo;s start, schools in the region have been fully or partially closed for an average of more than ten months\u0026mdash;ranging from 4.5 in Egypt to more than 14 in Iraq.[[footnote 18]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGlobally, the pandemic-era combination of school closures and loss of livelihoods could result in an average shortfall of 6.4 months, according to \u003ca href=\"/industries/education/our-insights/how-covid-19-caused-a-global-learning-crisis\"\u003eMcKinsey\u0026rsquo;s latest research\u003c/a\u003e. In addition, the loss of time in school, compounded by additional regression in learning, could mean that grade-three children from low- and middle-income countries will have levels of learning one year lower than expected by the time they reach grade ten.[[footnote 19]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUneven digital literacy and uneven access to affordable, reliable internet connections and devices have further deepened inequities in educational outcomes. A McKinsey analysis in the United States has shown that students from vulnerable households are less likely to experience quality remote instruction. The result is an estimated\nloss of more than 12 months of learning\u0026mdash;nearly double the average.[[footnote 20]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut in the MENAP countries (as in others), the pandemic has also accelerated the digital shift in education. Saudi Arabia, for example, has implemented a well-crafted, technology-driven response. During the pandemic, the Ministry of Education (MoE) introduced and then scaled up several major e-learning platforms (including Madrasati for primary and secondary students and Rawdati for kindergarteners) while it ramped up efforts to give needy students access to devices.[[footnote 21]] Initial user feedback suggests that both platforms have had significant benefits for students and teachers alike.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEven in countries with a limited digital infrastructure, the rapid shift to remote learning has accelerated the uptake of educational technologies that give vulnerable and remote populations access to education. Bahrain, Jordan, Lebanon, and Morocco have used TV channels to broadcast distance-learning content: the Alsama Project, for example, streams English-language lessons for children in Lebanese refugee camps. Jordan has also promoted the use of existing online platforms, such as Microsoft Teams and Edraak. Morocco and Oman have partnered with telecom companies to offer students free internet access on a wide variety of educational websites and online platforms.[[footnote 22]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eAn opportunity to reimagine the region\u0026rsquo;s educational systems\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCOVID-19 has spurred the imagination and created the potential for change. People in the MENAP region now have an opportunity to rethink how its educational systems can shape the citizens of tomorrow.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOur research has identified six elements of success for a reimagined educational system: technology-enabled learning for every child; enhanced teacher quality to improve student outcomes; technology as an enabler of mastery-based, personalized learning; whole-child education; the creation of pathways for lifelong learning; and structural enablers to allocate resources equitably.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eTechnology-enabled learning for every child\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEducational technology could improve access to quality education in the MENAP region, especially given its expanding penetration by the internet and smartphones. Tablets are now available for $35, which in some MENAP countries could put high-quality instruction directly in the hands of students and provide teachers with excellent, easy-to-follow lesson plans.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eGovernments could consider several ways of supporting tech-enabled instruction and better educational outcomes. To improve access to online resources, for example, education ministries could work with mobile operators to zero-rate educational websites, request that telecom providers shape bandwidth to prioritize education-related data and services, or consider lifting data caps on free internet access for students. Other moves that could support remote learning include enhancing the availability of voice-over-internet-protocol (VOIP) services, tapping universal-service funds, distributing more devices for home use (as Egypt did in response to school closures), and setting up free local Wi-Fi access points where students can upload work and download content.[[footnote 23]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe UAE\u0026rsquo;s MoE has taken a number of steps to ensure the successful implementation of distance learning.[[footnote 24]] Besides helping teachers to make the switch, the ministry established two advanced operations centers and facilitated a technical helpline for students and parents to ensure a smooth IT experience and effective communication between students and teachers. Families with no home internet connection received a free mobile-internet package, and the ministry also collaborated with Al Yah Satellite Communications to provide free satellite broadband services in areas lacking connectivity. Private schools were required to implement distance learning but allowed to use their own systems for that purpose.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eEnhanced teacher quality to improve student outcomes\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe importance of better teachers has been highlighted by school closures, which revealed variations in the quality of instruction.[[footnote 25]] Technology cannot replace a great teacher, who may change\na student\u0026rsquo;s life trajectory. However, it can reduce workloads and improve the quality of education through tech-enabled teacher training and development; simulation-based instruction, for example,\nis valuable and risk free. At the beginning of the pandemic, the UAE\u0026rsquo;s MoE conducted a one-week remote professional-training course for more than 25,000 government schoolteachers and administrators and more than 9,200 private-school teachers and principals. It also collaborated with Hamdan Bin Mohammed Smart University\nto launch a free online course about how to operate online classrooms.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eGood teachers are critical to the performance and educational growth of students: on average, high-performing teachers can raise the performance of students by 53 percentage points over that of similar students with low-performing teachers.[[footnote 26]] \u003ca href=\"/industries/education/our-insights/how-the-worlds-best-performing-school-systems-come-out-on-top\"\u003eTeachers now work\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;about 50 hours a week globally but spend only 20 to 40 percent of their time on instruction and engagement with students; the rest is devoted to administrative responsibilities, evaluation and feedback, preparation, and other nonteaching activities (Exhibit 2). As this workload continues to grow, \u003ca href=\"/industries/education/our-insights/how-artificial-intelligence-will-impact-k-12-teachers\"\u003etechnology could free up 20 to 30 percent\nof the time of teachers\u003c/a\u003e, allowing them to spend a greater proportion of the day engaging with students\u0026mdash;which could improve educational outcomes. For example, \u003ca href=\"/industries/education/our-insights/how-artificial-intelligence-will-impact-k-12-teachers\"\u003eAI and digital platforms could help to assess students\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;(Exhibit 3).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n\u003ch3\u003eTechnology as an enabler of personalized, mastery-based learning\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSeveral existing platforms, which already combine instruction and assessment with a variety of content and resources, provide real-time feedback to both students and teachers through data visualization dashboards. The use of these platforms could make it easier for schools to collect data, track educational outcomes, and intervene to correct course more frequently rather than rely on periodic standardized tests, such as PIRLS, PISA, and TIMSS, which are given every three years on average.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the MENAP region, ministries of education have used existing platforms and created new ones\nin response to the pandemic. Jordan, for example, used MS Teams and Edraak (an Arabic-language open-access platform) for both K\u0026ndash;12 and continuous learning. In March 2020, Morocco launched a\nnew remote-learning platform, Telmid TICE, which 600,000 students access daily. In Qatar, Mzeed, accessible via website or app, was developed to help students and teachers access textbooks in PDF format and to provide model questions and answers, as well as other tools.[[footnote 27]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAcross the board, we found that providing information and communications technology (ICT) for teachers rather than students works best. However, a blended approach, combining teacher- and student-focused technologies, may have a still more beneficial impact.[[footnote 28]] For example, teacher-focused technologies (such as data projection) promote maximum engagement between students and teachers and have been shown to raise PISA science scores. Giving students access to computers with internet connections (a student-focused approach) also improves scores by empowering students\nto work individually at school or at home. Increasing access to\u0026mdash;and combining\u0026mdash;these educational technologies could give students in the MENAP region a recipe for success.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eImproving teacher-focused technologies tailored to the needs of individual students is critical to help them reach grade-level and subject standards. In a study on K\u0026ndash;12 teachers in the region, 57 percent of those queried reported that the digital resources they received were not sufficient for their students to achieve appropriate educational standards.[[footnote 29]] The study showed that the most acute needs for digital enhancement are in elementary-school science, elementary-school English-language arts, and middle-school social studies. It is expected that a 75 percent increase in the use of digital tools will be required to meet the future needs of the MENAP region\u0026rsquo;s students in a personalized way.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eWhole-child education\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAn increasing amount of evidence suggests that teaching should focus on more than pure academics and instead foster a whole-child education.[[footnote 30]] In fact, the biggest predictor of success for students in the region is mindset: the 2018 PISA survey determined that a motivated mindset was twice as important as an orientation to the subject matter for \u003ca href=\"/industries/education/our-insights/how-to-improve-student-educational-outcomes-new-insights-from-data-analytics\"\u003ePISA science scores\u003c/a\u003e. Mindset comprises\nfive dimensions: \u003cem\u003emotivation calibration\u003c/em\u003e, the ability to identify what motivation means in day-to-day life; \u003cem\u003emotivation\u003c/em\u003e, the desire to succeed and receive good grades; \u003cem\u003einstrumental motivation\u003c/em\u003e, how useful the subject will be for future lives and careers; a \u003cem\u003esense of belonging\u003c/em\u003e, how accepted the learner feels in school; and \u003cem\u003etest anxiety\u003c/em\u003e, how anxious the learner is when taking a test.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 4]]\n\u003cp\u003eMotivation calibration was shown to be the factor contributing most to success (Exhibit 4): for example, \u003ca href=\"/industries/education/our-insights/how-to-improve-student-educational-outcomes-new-insights-from-data-analytics\"\u003estudents with good motivation calibration scored, on average, 14 percent higher\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;on PISA than those with poor motivation calibration, and low-income students with higher motivation calibration were more likely to succeed than low-income students with poor motivation calibration.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 4]]\n\u003cp\u003eAn educational system could therefore consider using a broader approach, going beyond the traditional acquisition of skills to encompass empowering mindsets. This goal will require competency frameworks to strengthen values and attitudes across the curriculum, a focus on future skills,\nand a reduced emphasis on technical competencies (given automation trends and the rapid obsolescence of knowledge).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eCreating pathways for lifelong learning\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRapidly accelerated shifts in degree offerings and delivery models mean that lifelong learning\nno longer starts in higher education: rather, it is a muscle that can be developed by high-school students, who can look beyond their brick-and-mortar schools for certifications.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe trend of preparing students for lifelong learning, especially in coding and digital literacy, has been accelerating globally. The MENAP region has a few best-practice cases. For instance, INJAZ Al-Arab,\na nongovernmental organization (NGO) that targets youth workforce readiness, financial literacy, and entrepreneurship, partners with 92,905 volunteers, 4,000 schools, 426 universities, and 13 ministries\nof education across the region. It has helped more than 4.4 million students to bridge the gap between education and the labor force.[[footnote 31]] In Lebanon, the nonprofit CodeBrave works with schools and NGOs to empower students from disadvantaged backgrounds, including refugees, by teaching them to teach themselves and solve problems, as well as digital literacy.[[footnote 32]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eStructural enablers to allocate resources equitably\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe MENAP countries could help unleash the potential of technology in the classroom by considering changes to policies and regulatory frameworks. Governments can, for example, use performance-based funding to align quality with resources and empower all children. They could also engage the private sector, which has the resources to\ndeliver quality education efficiently at the scale required to meet growing demand. In fact, governments might consider shifting their role from operators to enablers and regulators, using targeted funding to ensure access for underprivileged students.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinally, as educational systems shift from skills-based to values- and attitudes-based learning, parental engagement will become increasingly important. During the pandemic, Qatar and the UAE provided parents with guidelines and advice to help them\nfulfill their new role of supporting their children\u0026rsquo;s remote learning at home.[[footnote 33]] In Bahrain and Jordan, schools mostly used WhatsApp and Facebook to communicate with parents and update them about their children\u0026rsquo;s progress.[[footnote 34]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe time to reimagine and shape the future of education in the MENAP region is now\u0026mdash;and this has never seemed more urgent. As the social and economic toll of the COVID-19 crisis continues to unfold, innovative and timely investments in the region\u0026rsquo;s human capital are the surest way to help countries weather the crisis and prepare for a\nrapidly changing world. We see four broad actions to establish a new lifelong-learning model that would prepare the populations of the MENAP region for the future of work.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eInvest smartly in educational technology to improve digital literacy and support teachers inside and outside the classroom.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eAdopt holistic education frameworks that focus on values, mindsets, skills, and competencies.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eEmbed lifelong learning\u0026mdash;especially in basic technological literacy, workforce readiness, and cognitive skills\u0026mdash;across the education journey.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eEngage the private sector effectively to enhance the efficiency, delivery, and relevance of education.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese imperatives will require the mobilization of parents, students, teachers, school leaders, governments, and employers. Meanwhile, educational institutions will need to find new ways of fixing the old path and charting new paths and solutions\nto reimagine education going forward.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2022-07-26T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eJimmy de la Torre, Nancy Law, Gary Wong, and David Woo, \u0026ldquo;A global framework of reference on digital literacy skills for indicator 4.4.2,\u0026rdquo;
